questions.text: A patient having cough 3 weeks was started on ATT under NTEP. IP and CP were completed and then he tested smear negative for AFB on 2 samples. What’s the status of patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A) Treatment completed: While the patient did complete treatment, "Treatment Completed" is a distinct outcome category. It is used for patients who complete treatment but do not meet the criteria for "Cured" (e.g., they were initially smear-negative, or follow-up smears were not done/available). For an initially smear-positive patient with negative follow-up smears, "Cured" is the more specific and desired outcome.
  • • C) Improper follow-up: The description clearly states that follow-up smears were done ("tested smear negative for AFB on 2 samples"). This indicates proper follow-up, not improper.
  • • D) Failure: Treatment failure occurs when a patient remains smear-positive (or becomes smear-positive again) at the end of the treatment course, or if they continue to be smear-positive at the end of the intensive phase and do not convert. In this case, the patient became smear-negative, so failure is incorrect.

Blood bags are discarded in WHICH COLOUR?
A case of RTA was presenting to Emergency room. Disinfectant used for blood spill management on hospital floor :
Soiled throat swabs are discarded in:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A soiled throat swab is considered infectious waste because it is contaminated with human body fluids (saliva, mucus) and may contain pathogenic microorganisms.
  • • According to the Bio-Medical Waste Management Rules, 2016 (India), the Yellow bag is designated for:
  • • Human Anatomical Waste: Tissues, organs, body parts. Animal Anatomical Waste. Soiled Waste: Items contaminated with blood or body fluids, such as dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs, and beddings. Expired or Discarded Medicines. Microbiology & Biotechnology Waste: Laboratory cultures, live vaccines, and swabs. Since a soiled throat swab is an item contaminated with body fluids and is also a part of microbiological waste, it correctly belongs in the Yellow bag. Waste collected in yellow bags is typically sent for incineration or plasma pyrolysis to ensure complete destruction of all infectious agents.
  • • Why Other Colors Are Incorrect: B) Red: The red bag is used for contaminated recyclable waste, such as plastic items like IV tubes, catheters, syringes (without needles), and gloves. A throat swab is not typically recycled. C) Blue: The blue box or container is for glassware (like broken or discarded vials and ampoules) and metallic body implants. D) White: The white (translucent, puncture-proof) container is exclusively for "sharps" waste, which includes items that can cause cuts or puncture wounds, such as needles, scalpels, and blades.

questions.text: Most peripheral level of health care system in India/ health planning:
as per the sustainable development goals, The target for MMR is to achieve maternal deaths of:
Health care facilities provided in school is delivered through
For applied nutrition program, seeds and manure supply under school health services has been done by:
To promote health- span the best recommendation is:

options.label: D
options.text: Restrict caloric intake and increase exercise

questions.correct_answer: D. Restrict caloric intake and increase exercise
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Health-span refers to the period of life spent in good health, free from the chronic diseases and disabilities of aging. While all the options listed are beneficial, the combination of caloric restriction and increased exercise is widely recognized as the most powerful and comprehensive strategy for extending health-span.
  • • Synergistic Effects: Caloric restriction and exercise work on multiple, often overlapping, cellular pathways that combat aging. Together, they are more effective at improving metabolic health (like insulin sensitivity), reducing chronic inflammation, and promoting cellular repair than either intervention alone. Comprehensive Benefits: Restricting caloric intake helps reduce oxidative stress and triggers protective cellular processes. Exercise, particularly a mix of aerobic and resistance training, builds and maintains muscle mass and bone density, improves cardiovascular function, and boosts brain health. Combining them ensures you are losing fat while preserving metabolically crucial muscle, a key factor for healthy aging. While reducing stress (C) is vital for long-term health, and restricting caloric intake (A) or exercising (B) on their own are powerful, the synergistic combination (D) provides the most robust and evidence-backed foundation for a long and healthy life.

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The combination of symptoms and the highly restricted diet strongly points to Scurvy, a disease caused by severe Vitamin C deficiency.
  • • Dietary Clue: A diet containing only rice and pulses is completely devoid of fresh fruits and vegetables, which are the primary sources of Vitamin C. This type of diet is a classic cause of scurvy.
  • • Symptoms Explained: While often associated with bleeding gums, severe and chronic scurvy has debilitating effects on the musculoskeletal system.
  • • Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, which is crucial for the integrity of blood vessels. Its deficiency leads to weak capillaries that rupture easily, causing hemorrhages (bleeding) into muscles and joints, particularly in the legs. This internal bleeding results in intense pain, swelling, and muscle weakness. This directly explains why the farmers have difficulty standing and walking and need a stick for support. The "crossed gait" (or scissor gait) is likely an antalgic gait, an abnormal pattern of walking adopted to minimize pain. Preventing this would involve introducing sources of Vitamin C, such as citrus fruits, amla, guava, tomatoes, or leafy green vegetables.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Vitamin A: Deficiency of Vitamin A primarily causes vision problems (like night blindness and xerophthalmia) and skin issues. It does not typically present with these severe musculoskeletal symptoms. B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency causes osteomalacia in adults, leading to bone pain and muscle weakness. While the symptoms are similar, the diet described is most characteristically and completely lacking in Vitamin C. Furthermore, as farmers, they might have some sun exposure, which aids in Vitamin D synthesis. D. Vitamin B: This is too general. While specific B-vitamin deficiencies like Beriberi (Vitamin B1) or B12 deficiency can cause neurological damage leading to difficulty walking (peripheral neuropathy, ataxia), the combination of a diet completely lacking fresh produce and the specific mechanism of bleeding into muscles makes scurvy the most direct and fitting diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35 year old homeless man presented with a 1 month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest xray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait till TB culture results to start ATT

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The patient presents as a classic case of sputum-smear negative pulmonary tuberculosis. The clinical symptoms (fever, cough, weight loss) and the chest x-ray are highly suggestive of TB, but the initial sputum microscopy is negative. In this scenario, the NTEP diagnostic algorithm mandates the use of a more sensitive and rapid molecular test.
  • • The CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test), such as GeneXpert or TrueNat, is the recommended test for several key reasons:
  • • High Sensitivity: It is much more sensitive than sputum smear microscopy and can detect the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis even when the bacterial load is low (paucibacillary disease), which is common in smear-negative cases. Rapid Diagnosis: The test provides a result within a couple of hours, allowing for prompt initiation of treatment. Detects Drug Resistance: Crucially, the CBNAAT also simultaneously detects resistance to Rifampicin, the most important first-line anti-TB drug. This aligns with NTEP's policy of Universal Drug Susceptibility Testing (UDST) and ensures the patient is started on the correct treatment regimen from the beginning. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A) Repeat sputum smear: Given that two smears are already negative, repeating a low-sensitivity test is unlikely to yield a positive result and would only cause further delay in diagnosis. NTEP guidelines have moved away from this practice. C) Ask for line probe assay (LPA): LPA is a molecular test used primarily for drug susceptibility testing on samples that are already known to be positive for TB (either sputum smear-positive or culture-positive). It is not the initial diagnostic tool of choice for a smear-negative patient. D) Wait till TB culture results to start ATT: While culture is the gold standard for diagnosis, it is very slow, taking anywhere from 2 to 8 weeks to get a result. Making a symptomatic and potentially infectious patient wait this long is clinically and epidemiologically inappropriate and could lead to worsening disease and continued transmission.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between alanine dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. What type of study is being performed?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To determine the study type, we need to look at two key factors: how the study groups are selected and the timing of the data collection.
  • • It is a Cohort Study: The study begins by identifying two groups (cohorts) based on their exposure status: one group exposed to alanine dye (dye handlers) and another group not exposed (office clerks). It then compares the incidence of bladder cancer between these two groups. This "exposure-first" approach is the defining characteristic of a cohort study.
  • • It is Retrospective: The crucial detail is that the "Years of occupation were noted from records." This means the researcher is looking back in time. The exposure (working with the dye) and the outcome (developing cancer) have both already occurred before the study began. The entire study is reconstructed using historical data, making it a retrospective (or historical) cohort study.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Prospective cohort study: In a prospective study, the researcher would identify the exposed and unexposed groups in the present and then follow them forward into the future to see who develops the disease. This is not what is being described. C. Case-control study: This study design works in the opposite direction. It would start by identifying a group of people with bladder cancer (cases) and a group without it (controls), and then look backward in their history to determine their past exposure to the dye. D. Intervention and response: This describes an experimental study (like a clinical trial) where the researcher actively assigns an exposure or treatment to a group. The described study is observational; the researcher is only observing the effects of an existing occupational exposure.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population is tracked from childhood to adulthood. It Is observed that those with lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood and vice versa. This can be best described as-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Tracking is the specific epidemiological term used to describe the phenomenon where a physiological variable, such as blood pressure, cholesterol, or BMI, maintains its relative rank within a population distribution over a long period. The scenario described—where children with lower blood pressure tend to become adults with lower blood pressure, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood—is the exact definition of tracking. This concept is crucial in public health as it highlights the importance of monitoring and intervening on risk factors from an early age.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Rule of halves: This is an epidemiological rule related to the management of chronic diseases like hypertension. It states that roughly only half of all people with hypertension are diagnosed, only half of those diagnosed are treated, and only half of those treated are adequately controlled. It describes the cascade of care, not the persistence of BP levels over time. C. STEPwise approach: The WHO STEPwise approach (STEPS) is a standardized methodology for the surveillance of non-communicable disease risk factors in a population. It is a tool for data collection, not a term to describe the biological phenomenon of BP persistence. D. Primordial approach: This refers to primordial prevention, a strategy aimed at preventing the development of risk factors in the first place (e.g., promoting a healthy lifestyle in children to prevent them from ever developing high blood pressure). The phenomenon of tracking is the scientific basis that justifies the need for a primordial approach, but it is not the name of the phenomenon itself.

questions.text: A 30 week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papay, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they are abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counseling and information to the patients?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The scenario described involves a pregnant woman with a clear health issue (night blindness, suggesting Vitamin A deficiency) caused by a dietary misconception. The primary duty of providing household-level counseling, dispelling myths, and linking the community with health services falls squarely on the ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist).
  • • The ASHA is a community-based health activist selected from the village itself. Her core responsibilities include:
  • • Acting as the first point of contact for any health-related needs of the community. Making home visits to pregnant women to monitor their health. Providing counseling on essential topics like nutrition, rest, and dispelling local myths or misconceptions that could be harmful. Ensuring the pregnant woman receives antenatal check-ups, iron-folic acid supplements, and institutional delivery. In this case, it would be the ASHA's primary role to identify the dietary problem, counsel the woman that ripe papaya and mango are safe and nutritious during pregnancy, and encourage her to see the ANM for a check-up regarding her vision.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): The ANM is a trained health worker based at the Sub-Centre. While she provides counseling during clinical check-ups, her primary role is service delivery (e.g., conducting antenatal check-ups, administering immunizations). The ASHA is responsible for motivating and bringing the woman to the ANM. The initial, household-level counseling is the ASHA's duty. B. AWW (Anganwadi Worker): The AWW works under the ICDS scheme and is primarily responsible for supplementary nutrition and pre-school education. While she also counsels pregnant women on nutrition, the ASHA has a broader health mandate and is designated as the primary community health counselor and activist. C. Trained birth attendants (Dais): Their role has traditionally been to assist with childbirth itself. Modern health policy encourages institutional deliveries, and the role of traditional attendants has shifted. Comprehensive antenatal counseling on diet and nutrition is not their primary function.

questions.text: A 22 year old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The treatment for Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs) and Reproductive Tract Infections (RTIs) in India follows the Syndromic Case Management (SCM) approach, as recommended by the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO). This approach uses pre-packaged, color-coded kits to treat a specific syndrome (a set of signs and symptoms) without waiting for laboratory confirmation.
  • • The key clinical finding in this patient is the presence of erosions on the cervix upon speculum examination. This is a definitive sign of Cervicitis (inflammation of the cervix).
  • • The Gray Kit is the designated syndromic kit for the management of Cervicitis and Urethral Discharge. It contains medication to treat the most common causative organisms, Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. The minimal vaginal discharge is likely mucopurulent discharge originating from the inflamed cervix, which further supports the diagnosis of cervicitis over simple vaginitis.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Green Kit: The Green Kit is used to treat Vaginitis, which is characterized by abnormal vaginal discharge (often profuse, itchy, or foul-smelling) due to infections like Trichomoniasis or Bacterial Vaginosis. In simple vaginitis, the cervix typically appears healthy. The presence of cervical erosions points away from the Green Kit as the primary treatment. B. Red Kit: This is not a standard color for a kit managing this specific syndrome in the national guidelines. D. Yellow Kit: The Yellow Kit is used for the management of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), which is an infection of the upper genital tract. The key symptom for PID is lower abdominal pain, which was not mentioned in the patient's presentation.

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could have attributed to-

options.label: A
options.text: Years of life lost to morbidity

options.label: B
options.text: Years lost due to premature death

options.label: D
options.text: Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.correct_answer: B. Years lost due to premature death
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a public health metric that specifically measures the burden of premature mortality. It quantifies the number of years lost when a person dies before a predetermined standard age, often set at 70 or 75 years.
  • • The core idea behind YPLL is to give more weight to deaths that occur at younger ages. For example, a death at age 25 contributes far more "years of potential life lost" than a death at age 70. This helps public health officials identify and prioritize health problems that cause death in younger, otherwise productive, members of the population. It is a measure strictly related to mortality, not the quality of life while living.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Years of life lost to morbidity & D. Years lost to poor quality of life: These concepts relate to the time spent living with illness, disease, or in a state of less than full health. YPLL does not account for this; it only considers death. C. Years lost to disability: This is measured by a different, specific metric called Years Lived with Disability (YLD). A more comprehensive metric called the Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) combines both concepts: DALY = YPLL + YLD. This shows that YPLL is a distinct component that only accounts for premature death.

questions.text: In a 10 year old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The National Immunization Schedule provides booster doses of certain vaccines at specific ages to maintain immunity acquired during infancy. For a 10-year-old child, the schedule mandates a booster dose of the Td vaccine.
  • • Td stands for Tetanus and a reduced-dose (adult) diphtheria vaccine. This vaccine is given to boost the immunity against tetanus and diphtheria that was initially provided by the DPT/Pentavalent vaccines in early childhood. The diphtheria component is given in a lower dose to minimize reactions in older children and adults. Another dose of the Td vaccine is scheduled at 16 years of age. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Measles vaccine: The measles-containing vaccine (MMR) is given in two doses: the first at 9-12 months and the second at 16-24 months of age. The schedule is completed in early childhood. B. Rotavirus vaccine: This is an oral vaccine given only to infants at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age to protect against severe diarrhea. D. Hepatitis B vaccine: The Hepatitis B vaccine series is completed during infancy. It includes a birth dose followed by doses at 6, 10, and 14 weeks as part of the Pentavalent vaccine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan?

options.label: A
options.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.correct_answer: D. Setting up cobalt therapy units
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This is a question of historical fact related to international aid in healthcare. The Colombo Plan, established in 1951 for cooperative development in Asia and the Pacific, had several key initiatives in its early decades.
  • • One of the most significant and well-documented contributions of the Colombo Plan to cancer treatment was the donation of Cobalt-60 radiotherapy units by member countries, most notably Canada. In the 1950s and 1960s, Cobalt-60 therapy was a revolutionary technology for treating cancer with external beam radiation. Through the Colombo Plan, Canada provided these "Cobalt Bomb" machines to many developing nations, including India, which was instrumental in establishing modern radiotherapy facilities in the country for the first time.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer: This is incorrect due to the timeline. Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is a much more recent technology that only became clinically widespread in the 1990s and 2000s, decades after this specific Colombo Plan initiative. B. Human resource strengthening: While the Colombo Plan did involve training technical staff and doctors to operate the new equipment (a form of human resource strengthening), its most direct and tangible contribution to cancer treatment was providing the treatment technology itself. Option (D) is the specific action, whereas this is a broader, supporting activity. C. Setting up chemotherapy units: Although chemotherapy was being developed during the same era, the most famous and impactful technological contribution of the Colombo Plan to cancer care was specifically in the field of radiotherapy with the provision of Cobalt-60 machines.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation described—progressive spastic paraparesis with signs of upper motor neuron damage—is the classic manifestation of Neurolathyrism. This is a neurodegenerative disease directly linked to the consumption of a specific toxin.
  • • The Toxin and its Source: The toxin responsible for neurolathyrism is BOAA (β-N-oxalyl-amino-L-alanine). This neurotoxin is naturally present in the grass pea (Lathyrus sativus), known in India as khesari dal.
  • • Mechanism of Action: BOAA is an excitotoxin. It overstimulates glutamate receptors in the brain and spinal cord, leading to the death of motor neurons. This damage is irreversible and primarily affects the legs, causing the characteristic stiffness (spasticity) and weakness (paraparesis).
  • • Epidemiological Context: The scenario of a poor farmer with crop failure is the typical setting for lathyrism outbreaks. The grass pea is a very hardy legume that can survive extreme conditions like drought when other crops fail. During times of famine or food scarcity, impoverished populations are often forced to consume it as a major part of their diet for prolonged periods, leading to a toxic accumulation of BOAA.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Aflatoxin: This is a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus mold, commonly found on improperly stored grains and peanuts. It is a potent liver toxin (hepatotoxin) and can cause acute liver failure and liver cancer. It does not cause spastic paraparesis. C. Ergot Alkaloids: These toxins are produced by the Claviceps fungus growing on rye and other cereals. They cause Ergotism, which manifests as either gangrene of the limbs (due to vasoconstriction) or convulsions, spasms, and hallucinations. D. Fusarium toxin: This is a broad class of toxins from Fusarium molds on cereals. They are associated with various conditions, including esophageal cancer and alimentary toxic aleukia, but not the specific neurological syndrome of lathyrism.

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The management of tetanus prophylaxis after an injury is based on two key factors: the patient's tetanus vaccination history and the nature of the wound.
  • • Vaccination History: The patient has received a full course of vaccination, meaning he has been previously immunized and only requires a booster dose at appropriate intervals. Nature of the Wound: The injury is described as a "clean-cut wound without any bleeding," which classifies it as a clean, minor wound. Time Since Last Dose: The last dose was 10 years ago. According to standard medical guidelines for wound management, for a patient with a clean, minor wound who has completed their primary vaccination series, a booster dose of the tetanus toxoid (TT) or Td (Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine is recommended if it has been 10 or more years since their last dose. This single dose will boost the patient's active immunity and ensure they are protected.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine: This extensive treatment is incorrect. Human Tetanus Immunoglobulin (TIG) provides passive immunity and is only given for severe, contaminated, tetanus-prone wounds in individuals with an unknown or incomplete vaccination history. A full course of the vaccine is also not needed. B. Human tetanus immunoglobulin only: TIG is not indicated for a clean wound in a previously vaccinated individual. D. No treatment required: Because 10 years have passed since the last vaccination, the patient's immunity is considered to be waning. It is standard and best practice to administer a booster dose at this point to ensure adequate protection.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak?

options.label: A
options.text: Collect water from already leaking taps

options.label: B
options.text: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 min

options.label: C
options.text: Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage

options.label: D
options.text: Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.correct_answer: D. Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The primary goal when collecting a water sample for bacteriological examination is to ensure the sample is not contaminated by external bacteria during the collection process (aseptic technique). This ensures that any bacteria found are from the water supply itself.
  • • Collecting the sample from a gentle, non-splashing stream is a critical step in this aseptic procedure. After the tap has been disinfected and flushed at high pressure to clear the lines, the flow is deliberately reduced. A high-pressure, splashing stream can aerosolize water and pick up bacteria from the surrounding environment (like the sink basin, faucet exterior, or the collector's hands) and introduce them into the sterile sample bottle. This would contaminate the sample and lead to a false positive result. A gentle stream minimizes this risk, ensuring the water enters the bottle directly without picking up external contaminants.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A) Collect water from already leaking taps: This is incorrect. Leaking taps are a potential source of contamination as the stagnant, dripping water is exposed to the surrounding environment and is not representative of the water in the main pipe. B) Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 min: While flushing the tap for 2-3 minutes is a mandatory step before collection to clear stagnant water from the pipes, the sample itself is collected after this step and from a reduced, gentle flow. This option describes a preliminary step, not the specific technique for the final collection moment. C) Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: This is misleading. While the container is held near the tap, the most important instruction is to not touch the tap with the bottle, as this would directly contaminate the sample. The primary concern is preventing contamination, not spillage. Option (D) describes a more critical anti-contamination action.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as-
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is the specific term for the average daily intake level of a nutrient that is scientifically calculated to be sufficient to meet the requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group. The RDA is intended to be used as a goal for daily intake by individuals. If a person consistently consumes the RDA for a particular nutrient, they have a very high probability of meeting their individual physiological requirement for that nutrient.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Adequate Intake (AI): An AI is established when there is insufficient scientific evidence to determine an RDA. It is a recommended intake level based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group of healthy people. It is a less certain measure than an RDA. B. Dietary goal: This is a general, non-technical term. While the RDA is a type of dietary goal, "Recommended Dietary Allowance" is the precise, scientifically defined term for the definition given in the question. C. Estimated Average Requirement (EAR): This is the intake level estimated to meet the requirement of only half (50%) of the healthy individuals in a group. The EAR is used to assess the nutrient adequacy of populations and is the statistical basis from which the RDA is calculated (typically, RDA = EAR + 2 Standard Deviations). It is not a recommended goal for individuals, as it would be insufficient for 50% of people.

questions.text: A boys hostel has an outbreak of fever cases with headache, followed by the development of pleomorphic rashes sparing palms and soles. What is the next best step in the management of suspected cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Isolate for 6 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 72 hours of exposure

options.label: B
options.text: Isolate for 12 days after giving acyclovir, followed by VZIG within 48 hours of exposure

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of fever and headache followed by a pleomorphic rash (lesions in various stages like macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts simultaneously) that spares the palms and soles is a classic description of Varicella (Chickenpox).
  • • In managing a highly contagious disease like chickenpox, especially during an outbreak in a closed setting like a hostel, the primary and most important public health measure is to prevent further transmission. This is achieved through isolation.
  • • Infectious Period: A person with chickenpox is contagious from 1-2 days before the rash appears until all skin lesions have crusted over. Isolation Duration: This crusting process typically takes about 5 to 7 days from the onset of the rash. Therefore, isolating the suspected case for 6 days is the standard and most appropriate immediate action to control the spread of the virus within the hostel. Supportive care (like fever control and anti-itch lotions) would also be provided. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. & B. Options involving Acyclovir and VZIG: These are incorrect for routine management.
  • • Acyclovir: This antiviral medication is not routinely recommended for uncomplicated chickenpox in otherwise healthy children and adolescents. It is reserved for severe cases or high-risk groups (e.g., immunocompromised patients). VZIG (Varicella-Zoster Immunoglobulin): This is not a treatment for a patient who already has chickenpox. VZIG provides passive immunity and is used only for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to prevent or reduce the severity of the disease in susceptible, high-risk individuals (like a pregnant woman or an immunocompromised person) after they have been exposed. D. Only give VZIG: This is incorrect as VZIG is not used to treat an active infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is widely regarded as one of the most sensitive indicators of the overall health status of a community. It reflects the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of a wide range of healthcare services and the underlying socioeconomic conditions.
  • • An infant's ability to survive the first year of life is dependent on a multitude of factors, making the IMR a comprehensive summary measure. A low IMR suggests:
  • • Good Maternal Health: Healthy and well-nourished mothers. Effective Healthcare: High-quality antenatal, delivery, and postnatal care. Strong Child Health Services: High immunization coverage and effective management of childhood illnesses. Favorable Socioeconomic & Environmental Conditions: Access to clean water, adequate sanitation, and higher levels of female literacy. Because it is influenced by so many different components, the IMR is highly sensitive to change and serves as an excellent barometer of the overall health and well-being of a community.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Maternal mortality rate (MMR): While a crucial indicator, MMR is more specific to the quality of obstetric and maternal health services. It is also a statistically rarer event than infant death, making it a less stable indicator for smaller populations or shorter time frames. C. Immunization coverage: This is an excellent process indicator that measures the performance and reach of a specific health program. However, it does not capture the overall health outcome of the community or the quality of other essential services like sanitation or neonatal care. D. Disability-adjusted life years (DALY): The DALY is the most comprehensive measure of disease burden as it combines mortality and morbidity (illness/disability). However, it is very complex to calculate and requires extensive data, making it less practical for routine, timely monitoring of community health status compared to the more straightforward and readily available IMR.

questions.text: A student is doing research and he is including three parameters i.e. Life Expectancy at birth, Income and Knowledge. These parameters represent?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic created by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It is based on three key dimensions, which directly correspond to the parameters mentioned in the question:
  • • A long and healthy life: Measured by Life Expectancy at birth. Knowledge: Measured by a combination of the mean years of schooling for adults and the expected years of schooling for children. A decent standard of living: Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita. Since the student's research includes Life Expectancy, Knowledge, and Income, they are using the three core components of the Human Development Index.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. PQLI - Physical Quality of Life Index: This is an older index that was a forerunner to the HDI. It measures quality of life using three indicators: basic literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one. Crucially, it deliberately excludes income. C. HPI - Human Poverty Index: This former UNDP index was designed to measure deprivation in a country, focusing on negative aspects like the probability of not surviving to a certain age, illiteracy rates, and lack of access to clean water. It measures poverty, not overall development or attainment. D. GHI - Global Hunger Index: This is a specialized index that focuses exclusively on measuring hunger and malnutrition. Its indicators are undernourishment, child wasting, child stunting, and child mortality. It does not include income or life expectancy.

questions.text: Considering following which of the following is included in PQLI? 1. IMR 2. Literacy 3. Gross national product 4. Cost benefit
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) was developed in the 1970s as a way to measure the well-being and quality of life within a country by focusing on social outcomes rather than purely economic indicators like Gross National Product (GNP).
  • • The PQLI is a composite index made up of three specific indicators:
  • • Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) Basic Literacy Rate Life Expectancy at Age One Therefore, from the list provided in the question, IMR (1) and Literacy (2) are both components of the PGLI.
  • • Why the Other Items Are Incorrect 3. Gross national product: The PQLI was created specifically to be an alternative to economic measures like GNP. Its entire philosophy was to measure quality of life without being influenced by a country's income, so it explicitly excludes GNP. 4. Cost benefit: This is a method of economic analysis used to evaluate the feasibility of a project or decision. It is not a component of a national development index like the PQLI.

questions.text: A disease with IP is 2 to 14 days and median IP is 10 days. A person without vaccination certificate travelled from endemic area. What should be the quarantine period for this person?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The purpose of quarantine is to restrict the movement of a healthy person who has been potentially exposed to a communicable disease for a period of time to see if they develop symptoms. The duration of this period is determined by the maximum incubation period of the disease.
  • • The incubation period (IP) is the time from exposure to an infectious agent to the onset of symptoms. In this case, the IP ranges from 2 to 14 days. This means an exposed person could show symptoms as late as 14 days after their exposure. To ensure that the individual does not spread the disease to the community, they must be quarantined for the entire maximum possible duration of the incubation period.
  • • Minimum IP: 2 days Median IP: 10 days Maximum IP: 14 days Therefore, a quarantine period of 14 days is required to safely monitor the person until the risk of them developing the disease has passed.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. 2 days: This is the minimum IP. Releasing the person after 2 days would be dangerous, as they could still develop the disease anytime between day 3 and day 14. B. 10 days: This is the median IP, meaning half of the people who get sick will do so after 10 days. This is not a safe endpoint for quarantine. D. 28 days: This is twice the maximum incubation period and is an unnecessarily long and restrictive duration based on the given data.

questions.text: Correct sequence of steps of case control study 1. Matching 2. Selection of cases and controls 3. Analysis 4. Measurement of exposure
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A case-control study is a type of observational study that works backward from an outcome (disease) to a potential cause (exposure). The logical sequence of steps is crucial for the validity of the study.
  • • Selection of cases and controls (Step 2): This is the mandatory first step. The study design is defined by first identifying a group of individuals who have the disease or outcome of interest (the "cases") and a separate group of individuals who do not have the disease (the "controls").
  • • Matching (Step 1): Matching is a technique used during the selection of controls to make the control group more comparable to the case group. For each case, a control is selected who is similar in terms of key characteristics (like age, sex, socioeconomic status) that are not being studied but could influence the outcome. This step must be done after identifying cases and during the selection of controls, but before measuring the main exposure.
  • • Measurement of exposure (Step 4): Once the two groups (cases and controls) have been established, the researchers look back in time to collect data on the past exposure to the risk factor of interest for everyone in both groups. This can be done through interviews, questionnaires, or by reviewing medical or occupational records.
  • • Analysis (Step 3): This is the final step. After all the data on case/control status and exposure history has been collected, statistical analysis is performed. In a case-control study, this typically involves calculating the Odds Ratio (OR) to determine if there is a statistically significant association between the exposure and the disease.

questions.text: Age group of patients is 2,3,5,4,4,7,8,6. calculate median age for the group?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The median is the middle value of a data set after the numbers have been arranged in order. To find the median, you follow these steps:
  • • Arrange the data: First, arrange the ages in ascending order. Original data: 2, 3, 5, 4, 4, 7, 8, 6 Ordered data: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • • Find the middle value: Since there is an even number of data points (8 ages), the median is the average of the two middle numbers. In this case, the two middle numbers are the 4th and 5th values in the ordered list.
  • • The 4th value is 4. The 5th value is 5. Calculate the average: Find the average of these two middle numbers. (4 + 5) / 2 = 9 / 2 = 4.5

questions.text: A researcher was studying some drugs. He divided them based on their origin into 3 groups: plants, animals, minerals. Then he randomly chose few drugs from each group. This type of sampling is called
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The research method described involves two key steps that are the defining characteristics of Stratified Random Sampling:
  • • Stratification: The researcher first divides the entire population (all drugs) into distinct, non-overlapping subgroups, known as strata. In this case, the strata are created based on the drug's origin: plants, animals, and minerals.
  • • Random Sampling: After creating the strata, the researcher then proceeds to draw a random sample from each individual stratum.
  • • This method ensures that the final sample is representative of the overall population by guaranteeing that members from each subgroup (stratum) are included. It is particularly useful when the researcher wants to compare the subgroups or ensure that smaller subgroups are not missed by chance.
  • • How it Differs from Other Sampling Methods Simple Random Sampling: In this method, the researcher would select drugs from a single master list without any prior grouping, giving every drug an equal chance of being selected. Cluster Sampling: In cluster sampling, the researcher would divide the population into clusters (groups), randomly select a few whole clusters, and then sample all or some members from only the selected clusters. This is different from stratified sampling, where a sample is taken from every group. Systematic Sampling: This would involve selecting drugs from a list at a fixed interval (e.g., every 10th drug) after a random start.

questions.text: A researcher was studying effect of lifestyle modification on serum cholesterol. For this purpose he recruits 100 volunteers and measured their S. Cholesterol before and after lifestyle modification intervention. Which of the following test is most appropriate here?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To choose the correct statistical test, we need to consider the type of data and the study design.
  • • Data Type: The data being measured is serum cholesterol, which is a quantitative (continuous) variable. Study Design: The study measures cholesterol levels in the same group of 100 volunteers at two different points in time—before and after the intervention. This means the two sets of data are not independent; they are paired or dependent. The Paired T-test is specifically designed to compare the means of two related groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. Since this study compares the mean cholesterol level of the same group before and after an intervention, the Paired T-test is the perfect choice.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Unpaired T-test: This test is used to compare the means of two independent or unrelated groups (e.g., comparing a group that received the intervention to a separate control group that did not). C. Chi-square test: This test is used for analyzing categorical data (e.g., comparing the proportion of people with "high" vs. "normal" cholesterol between two groups). It is not used for quantitative data like actual cholesterol values. D. McNemar test: This test is used for paired categorical data. It would be appropriate if the outcome was a "yes/no" category (e.g., classifying each person as having high cholesterol or not, both before and after), but not for continuous measurements like serum cholesterol levels.

questions.text: The marked structure is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The image displays the Demographic Transition Model, which illustrates how a country's population changes over time. The model tracks three main lines: the Birth Rate, the Death Rate, and the total Population Growth.
  • • The line marked with the red star represents the Death Rate. Here is why:
  • • Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate and death rate are high and fluctuating, leading to stable population growth. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): This stage is defined by a sharp and rapid decline in the Death Rate. This is due to improvements in public health, sanitation, food supply, and basic medicine. The marked line clearly shows this dramatic drop. Stages 3 & 4: The death rate continues to fall and then stabilizes at a low level. The other line that starts high (unmarked) is the Birth Rate, which remains high during Stage 2 and only begins to fall in Stage 3. The large gap created between the falling death rate and the high birth rate leads to the rapid Population Growth shown by the orange line.

questions.text: Considering demographic cycle which of the following is the correct sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: Early expanding, late expanding, high stationery, low stationery

options.label: B
options.text: High stationery, Early expanding, late expanding, low stationery

options.label: C
options.text: High stationery, low stationery, Early expanding, late expanding

options.label: D
options.text: High stationery, late expanding, low stationery, Early expanding

questions.correct_answer: B. High stationery, Early expanding, late expanding, low stationery
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The demographic cycle, also known as the Demographic Transition Model, describes the historical process of population change as a country develops from a pre-industrial to an industrialized society. The cycle progresses through four distinct stages in a specific order:
  • • Stage 1: High Stationary This is the pre-industrial stage, characterized by high birth rates and high death rates. Both rates are unstable and fluctuate with events like famines and epidemics. As a result, the total population remains low and stable.
  • • Stage 2: Early Expanding In this stage, the death rate begins to decline rapidly due to improvements in public health, sanitation, and food supply. However, the birth rate remains high, leading to a significant gap between the two. This gap results in a period of rapid population growth, often called a "population explosion."
  • • Stage 3: Late Expanding The death rate continues to decline but at a slower pace. The key event in this stage is that the birth rate starts to fall significantly due to factors like increased female education, access to contraception, and urbanization. The population continues to grow, but the rate of growth slows down. India is currently in this stage.
  • • Stage 4: Low Stationary This stage is characteristic of developed, industrialized countries. Both the birth rate and death rate are low and stable. This leads to zero population growth (ZPG) or a very slow increase, and the population size stabilizes at a new, much higher level than in Stage 1.

questions.text: A women underwent normal delivery. PPIUCD should be inserted within
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • PPIUCD stands for Postpartum Intrauterine Contraceptive Device. It is a crucial family planning method that provides long-acting, reversible contraception to a woman soon after she has given birth.
  • • According to the guidelines from the World Health Organization (WHO) and India's Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, there are specific timeframes for inserting an IUD after delivery. The immediate postpartum period is considered a key window of opportunity. PPIUCD insertion is recommended within 48 hours of delivery. This includes:
  • • Post-placental insertion: Done within 10 minutes of the delivery of the placenta. Immediate postpartum insertion: Done after 10 minutes but up to 48 hours following delivery. The rationale for this 48-hour window is that it is safe, effective, and convenient, as contraception can be initiated before the mother is discharged from the health facility.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. 6 days: The period between 48 hours and 6 weeks postpartum is generally avoided for IUD insertion. During this time, the uterus is rapidly shrinking (involution), which significantly increases the risk of the device being expelled. C. 24 hours: While insertion within 24 hours is correct, the standard accepted window extends up to 48 hours. Therefore, "within 48 hours" is the more complete and accurate answer that defines this specific insertion period. D. 6 weeks: Insertion at or after 6 weeks is known as interval insertion. This is also a safe and common time to place an IUD during a routine postnatal visit, but it is not considered PPIUCD. The PPIUCD method is specifically designed to utilize the opportunity immediately following childbirth.

questions.text: The given formula is related to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The formula shown in the image is: Number of live births in the same period Number of maternal deaths in a given period ? ×1000 or 100,000
  • • This formula measures the risk of a woman dying as a result of pregnancy, childbirth, or postpartum complications relative to the number of live births. It is a key indicator of the quality and safety of obstetric care in a region.
  • • Here is the crucial distinction between the terms:
  • • Maternal Mortality RATIO (MMRatio): This uses the number of live births as the denominator. This is the most widely used indicator globally (including by WHO and for the SDGs) to measure obstetric risk. The formula in the question is the definition of the MMRatio. Maternal Mortality RATE (MMRate): The technically correct denominator for a "rate" is the total population at risk, which in this case would be the total number of women of reproductive age (15-49 years). In many textbooks and examinations, the term "Maternal Mortality Rate" is used loosely to refer to the ratio. Therefore, recognizing that the formula compares maternal deaths to live births leads to selecting this option.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B) Maternal mortality ratio: While this is the technically correct term for the formula, given the options, the question likely uses "rate" and "ratio" interchangeably. C) Fertility rate: This measures the incidence of births, not deaths. For example, the general fertility rate is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age. D) Perinatal mortality rate: This measures deaths occurring around the time of birth, specifically stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life, relative to the total number of births. It does not measure maternal deaths.

questions.text: In a village there are 4000 live birth and 6 maternal deaths where 1 died because of sepsis, 1 died because of snake bite, 1 died because of accident, 1 died because of eclampsia, 1 died because of obstructed labor and 1 died because of ectopic pregnancy. Calculate maternal mortality ratio?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To calculate the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR), we need to follow two main steps: first, identify the true number of maternal deaths, and second, apply the standard formula.
  • • Step 1: Identify the Number of True Maternal Deaths
  • • A maternal death is defined by the WHO as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of the end of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from accidental or incidental causes.
  • • Let's analyze the 6 reported deaths:
  • • Sepsis: A direct obstetric cause. (Yes, this is a maternal death) Snake bite: An accidental/incidental cause. (No, this is not a maternal death) Accident: An accidental/incidental cause. (No, this is not a maternal death) Eclampsia: A direct obstetric cause. (Yes, this is a maternal death) Obstructed labor: A direct obstetric cause. (Yes, this is a maternal death) Ectopic pregnancy: A direct obstetric cause. (Yes, this is a maternal death) Therefore, the actual number of maternal deaths to be used in the calculation is 4.
  • • Step 2: Calculate the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)
  • • The formula for MMR is: MMR= Total Number of Live Births Total Number of Maternal Deaths ? ×100,000
  • • Plugging in the values from the village: MMR= 4000 4 ? ×100,000
  • • MMR=0.001×100,000
  • • MMR=100
  • • The Maternal Mortality Ratio for the village is 100 per 100,000 live births.

questions.text: In a village of 30,000 population there are 500 live birth and 10 still birth, Neonatal deaths are 20 and among them 9 deaths in first 7 days. What is the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate in the given case?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • To calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR), you need the correct formula and the specific data points from the scenario.
  • • Step 1: State the Formula
  • • The formula for the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is: ENMR= Total number of live births in the same year Number of infant deaths in the first 7 days of life ? ×1000
  • • Step 2: Identify the Correct Values
  • • From the data provided:
  • • Number of deaths in the first 7 days (early neonatal deaths) = 9 Total number of live births = 500 (Note: The total population, number of stillbirths, and total neonatal deaths are not used for this specific calculation).
  • • Step 3: Calculate the ENMR
  • • Plug the values into the formula: ENMR= 9/500 ×1000
  • • ENMR=0.018×1000
  • • ENMR=18
  • • Therefore, the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is 18 per 1,000 live births.

questions.text: Under Ayushman Bharat school health services which is not true?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Ayushman Bharat School Health and Wellness Program is a comprehensive initiative by the Government of India to strengthen health promotion and disease prevention services in schools. While Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation is a critical component of this program to combat anemia among adolescents, it is administered weekly, not monthly.
  • • The specific program for this is the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) program. Under WIFS, school-going adolescent boys and girls are provided one IFA tablet every week throughout the year. Therefore, the statement "Monthly IFA" is incorrect.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Correct Components The other options are all true components of the services delivered under the school health program:
  • • B. Sanitary napkin: Promoting menstrual hygiene management, which includes creating awareness and improving access to sanitary napkins, is an integral part of the program. C. Screening: Regular health screening is a cornerstone of the school health program, building upon the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) to screen for defects, deficiencies, diseases, and developmental delays. D. Deworming: The National Deworming Day initiative, which involves bi-annual mass administration of deworming tablets (Albendazole) to children, is a key public health program delivered through the school platform.

questions.text: Full form of given
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) is a major initiative launched by the Government of India in 2011 to reduce out-of-pocket expenses for pregnant women and sick newborns. The name translates to "Mother and Infant Protection Program."
  • • The primary goal of the program is to encourage women to deliver in public health institutions by making delivery and infant care completely free, thereby aiming to reduce maternal and infant mortality rates.
  • • Key entitlements under JSSK include completely free and cashless services for:
  • • Pregnant Women: Free delivery (including caesarean sections), drugs, diagnostics, blood transfusions, diet during their stay, and transport services. Sick Newborns: Free treatment, drugs, diagnostics, and transport for up to 30 days after birth.

questions.text: Given logo is related to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The logo for the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India is very distinct. It typically features two hands, with one hand giving a blister pack of Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) tablets to the other. This imagery directly represents the core strategy of the program, which is to cure leprosy through the free and accessible provision of MDT. The logo often includes an image of Mahatma Gandhi, who was a fervent advocate for the rights and care of people affected by leprosy.
  • • The NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme aimed at eliminating leprosy as a public health problem in India by providing early case detection and regular, complete treatment.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. NTEP (National Tuberculosis Elimination Program): This program is focused on eliminating Tuberculosis (TB). Its branding and logo are different, often featuring imagery related to lungs and the slogan "TB Harega Desh Jeetega." C. JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana): This is a safe motherhood scheme that provides conditional cash transfers to promote institutional deliveries. Its branding is focused on mother and child imagery. D. PMJAY (Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana): This is the national health insurance scheme under Ayushman Bharat. It has its own distinct and widely recognized logo for providing hospitalization coverage.

questions.text: Identify given image and it is related to
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • SAPNA is a key communication and social mobilization strategy under India's National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP). It is not a single character, but a comprehensive campaign aimed at:
  • • Raising Awareness: Educating the public about the signs and symptoms of leprosy. Promoting Self-Reporting: Encouraging people with potential symptoms to come forward for diagnosis. Reducing Stigma: Normalizing the disease and promoting the social inclusion of persons affected by leprosy, emphasizing that it is completely curable with Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT). The name "Sapna," which means "dream" in Hindi, is used to represent the goal of a leprosy-free India where affected individuals can live with dignity.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. MEENA-LEPROSY: Meena is a famous animated character created by UNICEF for South Asia. She is a young girl who champions a wide range of issues related to child rights, girls' education, and health, but she is not a specific mascot for the leprosy program. C. MEERA-HIV: This is not a recognized national campaign name or mascot for the HIV/AIDS control program in India, which is run by the National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO). D. TRIPTI-MALARIA: This is not a known mascot or campaign name for India's malaria control program (now under the National Center for Vector Borne Diseases Control).

questions.text: In Indian diet 60-70% thiamine comes from which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • In a typical Indian diet, cereals and millets such as rice, wheat, jowar, and bajra form the staple food and constitute the largest portion of daily energy intake. Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is primarily found in the outer layers (bran) and germ of these grains.
  • • Because these grains are consumed in such large quantities as the main component of most meals, they become the principal source of thiamine for the majority of the population, contributing an estimated 60-70% of the total daily intake.
  • • It is important to note that the processing of these grains significantly affects their thiamine content. Whole grains (like whole wheat flour and brown rice) are rich in thiamine, whereas highly polished rice and refined flour (maida) have very little, as the nutrient-rich bran and germ are removed. This is why a diet based heavily on polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency (Beriberi).

questions.text: A patient with bilateral pedal edema and hepato-splenomegly. History revealed consuming mustard oil which was adulterated. Most sensitive test for detecting adulteration.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The clinical presentation of bilateral pedal edema (swelling of the feet) and hepato-splenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen) after consuming adulterated mustard oil is a classic sign of Epidemic Dropsy.
  • • The Cause: Epidemic Dropsy is caused by the consumption of edible oils (most commonly mustard oil) that have been adulterated with oil from the Argemone mexicana plant. This adulteration introduces toxic alkaloids, primarily Sanguinarine, into the oil. The Test: To detect this specific adulteration, different tests are available with varying levels of sensitivity. Paper Chromatography is a highly sensitive and specific laboratory technique. It is used to separate the chemical components of a mixture. In this case, it can effectively separate and identify the toxic Sanguinarine alkaloid from the oil sample, confirming the presence of Argemone oil even at low concentrations. It is considered a reliable confirmatory test. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Methylene blue: The Methylene Blue Reduction Test is used to assess the microbial quality of milk, not to detect adulterants in oil. C. Phosphatase test: This test is used to verify the proper pasteurization of milk. It has no role in testing edible oils. D. Nitric acid test: This is a common screening test or field test for Argemone oil. While useful for rapid detection (it produces a reddish-brown color if Argemone oil is present), it is less sensitive than paper chromatography and may not detect low levels of adulteration. The question asks for the most sensitive test, which is paper chromatography.

questions.text: The image given is used to mesure?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The Kata Thermometer is a specialized instrument specifically designed to measure the cooling power of the air. It does not measure air temperature itself, but rather the rate at which a warm object loses heat to its surroundings.
  • • "Cooling power" is a composite measure that integrates the combined effects of air temperature, air movement (wind), and humidity on heat loss. The thermometer works by timing how long it takes for its alcohol column to cool between two fixed points (typically 38°C and 35°C), simulating the heat loss from a surface at body temperature. A rapid cooling time indicates high cooling power (e.g., in a cold, windy environment), while a slow cooling time indicates low cooling power (e.g., in a hot, still, humid environment).
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Humidity: This is measured using a Hygrometer or a Sling Psychrometer. C. Temperature: Standard air temperature is measured with a regular thermometer. D. Radiant heat: This is measured using a Globe Thermometer, which has a large, black copper sphere to absorb heat radiated from surrounding surfaces.

questions.text: De Chaumont criteria for ventilation is based on
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The De Chaumont criteria refer to a long-standing principle in public health and ventilation engineering where the concentration of Carbon Dioxide (CO2) is used as an indicator for the adequacy of ventilation in an occupied space.
  • • The rationale is as follows:
  • • Humans are the primary source of indoor air contaminants in many settings (e.g., classrooms, offices). Through respiration, they release CO2 as well as numerous other bio-effluents (body odors, organic compounds) that can lead to discomfort and a feeling of "stuffiness." It is difficult and impractical to measure all the various bio-effluents directly. However, the amount of CO2 released is directly proportional to the number of people in the room and inversely proportional to the rate of fresh air supply (ventilation). Therefore, CO2 serves as an excellent and easily measurable surrogate or proxy indicator for the overall level of human-generated pollutants. The De Chaumont criteria set a maximum permissible CO2 concentration (classically around 1000 parts per million), above which ventilation is deemed insufficient to maintain acceptable indoor air quality.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. O2 (Oxygen): The decrease in oxygen levels in a typically occupied room is very small and not a sensitive enough measure to assess ventilation quality. C. Humidity & D. Temperature: While humidity and temperature are critical components of thermal comfort, they are not reliable indicators of ventilation in terms of fresh air exchange. A room can be at a comfortable temperature and humidity due to an air conditioner that recirculates stale air, yet have very poor ventilation and high levels of CO2 and other pollutants.

questions.text: Consider following phases in disaster managment 1. Preparedness 2. Mitigation 3. Response 4. Rehabilitation Which of the following is true about recovery phase?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The question asks which of the given steps are part of the Recovery phase of disaster management. To understand this, let's look at the standard Disaster Management Cycle.
  • • The cycle is typically divided into four phases: Mitigation, Preparedness, Response, and Recovery.
  • • Mitigation & 2. Preparedness: These are pre-disaster phases.
  • • Mitigation involves actions to prevent or reduce the impact of a disaster (e.g., building earthquake-resistant structures). Preparedness involves planning and getting ready to act when a disaster strikes (e.g., creating evacuation plans, conducting drills). 3. Response & 4. Recovery (including Rehabilitation): These are post-disaster phases.
  • • The Response phase includes immediate actions taken during and right after a disaster to save lives and meet basic needs (e.g., search and rescue, emergency medical aid, providing food and shelter). The Recovery phase begins as the immediate emergency (response) phase ends. Its goal is to restore the community to normal. Recovery is a long-term process that includes: Rehabilitation (4): This is a core component of recovery, focusing on restoring livelihoods, repairing infrastructure, and providing psychosocial support. Reconstruction: Rebuilding physical structures, often with improvements ("building back better"). While Response and Recovery are distinct phases, there is a significant overlap. The Recovery process starts during the later stages of the Response phase. Therefore, in the broad context of post-disaster actions that lead a community back to normalcy, both the immediate Response (3) and the long-term Rehabilitation (4) are considered integral parts of the overall recovery effort.

questions.text: Different interpretation of words is which type of barrier
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A Semantic Barrier in communication occurs when there is a misunderstanding related to the meaning of words, signs, symbols, or phrases. The word "semantic" itself refers to the meaning of language. This type of barrier arises when the sender and receiver interpret the same word or message differently.
  • • Examples of semantic barriers include:
  • • Words with multiple meanings: The word "run" can mean the act of moving fast, a tear in a stocking, or a political campaign. Technical Jargon: A doctor using complex medical terms that a patient doesn't understand. Denotation and Connotation: A word's literal dictionary meaning (denotation) may be clear, but its implied emotional meaning (connotation) can be misunderstood. For instance, "cheap" can mean inexpensive or low-quality. The problem described—"different interpretation of words"—is the very definition of a semantic barrier.
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Cultural Barrier: This relates to misunderstandings arising from different cultural norms, values, gestures, and social etiquette, which is broader than just the meaning of words. C. Physiological Barrier: This is a physical issue that prevents effective communication, such as hearing impairment, poor eyesight, or a speech impediment. D. Psychological Barrier: This refers to mental or emotional factors that act as a barrier, such as prejudice, closed-mindedness, lack of attention, or high emotional states like anger or fear.

questions.text: Motivation model consist of awareness, motivation and ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The sequence "Awareness, Motivation, Action" represents a fundamental and widely recognized model of behavior change. It describes the logical progression an individual goes through when adopting a new behavior or working towards a goal.
  • • Awareness: This is the first stage where an individual becomes conscious of a need, a problem, or a goal. They recognize that something needs to change or be achieved. Motivation: This is the second stage where the desire, drive, or will to make a change is developed. After becoming aware, the individual weighs the pros and cons and builds the internal or external motivation to proceed. Action: This is the logical third and final stage. It is the "doing" phase where the individual converts their awareness and motivation into concrete steps and implementation. It involves actively engaging in the behaviors required to achieve the desired outcome. This model is a simplified framework used in various fields, from health promotion and psychology to marketing (where it is similar to the AIDA - Awareness, Interest, Desire, Action - model).
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect B. Contemplation: This is the act of thinking about something. In behavior change models (like the Transtheoretical Model), contemplation happens before a firm decision to act and is part of what builds motivation, it does not follow it. C. Reflection: This is the process of looking back on something. It typically occurs after an action has been taken to evaluate its success or to learn from it. D. Repent: This term relates to feeling remorse for a past wrongdoing and is not part of a standard behavioral or motivational model.

questions.text: In the ice lined refrigerator which vaccine is kept at lowest level below?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The storage of vaccines in an Ice Lined Refrigerator (ILR) follows a specific protocol based on the temperature gradient inside the refrigerator and the heat/freeze sensitivity of each vaccine.
  • • Temperature Gradient in an ILR: An ILR is designed to be coldest at the bottom and warmest at the top, while maintaining an overall temperature range of +2°C to +8°C. Vaccine Sensitivity: Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is the most heat-sensitive vaccine in the immunization schedule, but it is not damaged by freezing. Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV), along with others like Pentavalent and Td, is freeze-sensitive. Freezing destroys their potency. Based on these principles, OPV is always kept at the lowest level (bottom) of the ILR basket. This placement ensures it stays in the coldest part of the refrigerator, giving it maximum protection against heat damage.
  • • Placement of Other Vaccines B. BCG and C. MR: These vaccines are also heat-sensitive and are kept in the designated basket, but the prime position at the bottom is reserved for the most heat-sensitive vaccine, OPV. D. IPV: As a freeze-sensitive vaccine, IPV must be kept in the upper part of the refrigerator. Placing it at the bottom, where the temperature is lowest, would risk accidental freezing and render the vaccine ineffective.

questions.text: Ice berg phenomenon shown by
5 year old with diphtheria came to clinic what should be done for his 2 year brother who is fully vaccinated.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The management of a close contact of a confirmed diphtheria case involves two key considerations: eradicating any potential bacteria they may be carrying and ensuring their own immunity is up-to-date.
  • • Antibiotic Chemoprophylaxis: All close contacts of a diphtheria case, regardless of their immunization status, must receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis. This is to eliminate the Corynebacterium diphtheriae bacteria, preventing the contact from becoming an asymptomatic carrier and spreading the disease further. The recommended drug is either a single intramuscular dose of Benzathine Penicillin G or a 7-day course of oral erythromycin. Therefore, giving penicillin is a mandatory step.
  • • Immunization Status: The 2-year-old brother is described as "fully vaccinated." According to India's National Immunization Schedule, a fully vaccinated 2-year-old has received three primary doses of the DPT vaccine and a booster dose between 16-24 months. This means his immunity is robust and up-to-date. A booster dose of the vaccine is not required at this time.
  • • Since antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary but a vaccine booster is not, the single best management step is to provide only penicillin (or an equivalent antibiotic).
  • • Why the Other Options Are Incorrect A. Do nothing: This is incorrect and dangerous. Even a fully immunized person can temporarily carry and transmit the bacteria. Antibiotic prophylaxis is essential to break the chain of transmission. B. Only antitoxin: Diphtheria antitoxin is a treatment used to neutralize the toxin in patients who have active, clinical diphtheria. It is not used for prophylaxis in asymptomatic contacts due to the high risk of severe allergic reactions. D. Only vaccine: A vaccine is not needed as the child is already fully immunized and up-to-date. Furthermore, this option omits the crucial step of antibiotic prophylaxis.
